did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Va.
did.unittitle: Olin P. Keyes Coal Mining Prints c.1970
did.abstract: Eight different black and white prints depicting common coal mining scenes in Bluefield, WV created by native artist Olin P. Keyes in 1970.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Olin P. Keyes Coal Mining Prints, Ms2010-035, Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Olin P. Keyes Coal Mining Prints were purchased in 2010.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The processing, arrangement, and description of the Olin P. Keyes Coal Mining Prints were commenced and completed in June, 2010

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Olin O. Keyes is an artist native to West Virginia. After he was discharged from the Marine Corps in 1954, he studied engineering at Virginia Tech and graduated in 1959. His work is showcased in private collections and business offices across West Virginia coal country as well as in the Craft Memorial Library in Bluefield, WV. His pictures show technical insight as well as a close connection to his human subjects. Olin parents were Carol and Cynthia Morris Keyes and he has two sisters: Renna Carol Keyes, who died in 2010, and Lois Keyes Small.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of eight different prints depicting various common coal mining scenes in West Virginia as well as an "about the artist" fact sheet. The prints are black and white and are illustrated in a simplistic, comic book-like style. Some prints contain penciled-in titles.

The first print depicts an above-ground wooden structure; the second shows a man operating a large underground machine; the third illustrates a miner's work kit; the fourth illustrates two men working a drilling machine; the fifth shows two men emerging from an underground tunnel and is entitled, "Sunlight Again"; the sixth shows a man steering a mule cart and is entitled, "Main Line"; the seventh depicts a man picking up a large piece of coal and is entitled, "Hand Loader"; and the eighth shows two miners working underground and is entitled, "Shot Man."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged by material type.
